history.content:
I'm an intern there right now. I found out about it from an internship fair back in February. The application itself is online on the LBL website though.

- - -

1) Know what you're interested in working/researching on

2) Find relevant scientists at LBNL

3) Email, phone, or ask to have coffee with them.  Say why you're interested, have your resume ready, etc.

4) If it goes well, the LBNL scientist will initiate the HR hiring process and it's pretty standard from there.

You can do this any time of year; no need to wait and no applications.  I've gotten two jobs at LBNL through connections on campus, given that faculty often interact with scientists up at LBNL (if they are not also scientists at LBNL themselves!).

If you're interested in specific intern programs made for high school / university students, then that's a different story with a set timeline, probably.
